hopobject.name: Page
hopobject.body: We used to work together prix du voltarenplast But to his credit, Goss didn’t resort to the traditional rock’n’roll escape routes of drink or drugs. That said, in his early days in LA, he admits his and Luke’s relationship suffered. “That was a big loss. We felt we needed a break from each other. Luke to this day is still one of my best friends.” Do they see each other regularly? “Fairly. We speak to each other – we play video games nearly every night together; Bad Company,” he grins. But through it all – and there was also the end, in 2010, of his 10-year relationship with the American-Cuban MTV presenter Daisy Fuentes – Goss kept the faith. “It’s my family, and my country, that has kept me going,” he says, full of emotion. “I’m a British man, I’m a London boy, and I’m my mother’s son.” At this, he chokes up. Recovering, he starts talking about his grandfather. One of the many tattoos on his gym-fit body is of his birth date. “He was a healer,” he says. “I do healing.” I ask for some examples. “There was a fan that had cancer, and she asked me to give her healing. It was in the Gossy Room and I gave her healing after the show.” And she’s cured? He nods. “I’m not saying it’s because of me. Maybe a state of mind. But it’s something that my granddad told me to pursue and not be ashamed of. Yeah.” I state the obvious – that people will be sceptical, and take the mickey. “I couldn’t give a s---,” Goss replies. “I know what I feel. And I respect sceptics. Do I want Big Foot to exist? I’d love it if Big Foot existed. Am I sceptical? Yeah.”
